holdings.text: The Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 (Act XL of 1948) is intra vires the Legislature of the State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: the Provincial Legislature can invest the courts constituted by it with power and jurisdiction to try every cause or matter that can be dealt with by a court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 1 List II encompasses administration of justice, constitution and organization of courts, including general jurisdiction over all civil matters; entries 53 List I and 2 List II confer only special/additional jurisdiction; historical practice and avoidance of absurdity support broad interpretation.

holdings.text: Section 4 of the Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 is intra vires and constitutes valid conditional legislation, not an invalid delegation of legislative power.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether section 4 of the Act operates as a delegation of legislative power, I entirely agree with the reasoning and conclusion of my learned brother Das

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature fixed policy, initial limit (Rs10,000) and maximum (Rs25,000) in ss 3-4; government determines only timing of extension via notification; follows Queen v Burah as conditional legislation; distinguishes Jitendranath Gupta.

holdings.text: The Bombay High Court does not have jurisdiction to try the suit, as it is cognizable by the City Civil Court under the Act and notification.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 12 bars High Court jurisdiction over suits cognizable by City Court; suit value within enhanced limit under valid s4 notification; Act valid.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in holding s4 ultra vires; Act and s4 valid; reverses High Court judgment on jurisdiction.
